<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">As to the 2013 tranche, 65,754 shares correspond to the period from August&nbsp;25, 2012 to the June&nbsp;21, 2013 modification of the award. This portion vested on
August&nbsp;24, 2013 based on services provided. The remaining 14,246 shares of the 2013 tranche (corresponding to the period from June&nbsp;21, 2013 through August&nbsp;24, 2013) were also scheduled to vest on August&nbsp;24, 2013, but 50% of those
shares were forfeited based on relative TSR performance from August&nbsp;25, 2012 through August&nbsp;24, 2013. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Includes both the 2015 tranche vesting on August&nbsp;24, 2016 as well as the additional 100,000 RSUs vesting on that date. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Includes both the 2020 tranche vesting on August&nbsp;24, 2021 as well as the additional 100,000 RSUs vesting on that date. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">25 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Dividend Equivalents</I>. At his request, Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s RSU awards do not
participate in dividend equivalents. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Ownership Guidelines.</I> Under the Company&#146;s stock ownership guidelines,
Mr.&nbsp;Cook is expected to own shares of Company common stock that have a value equal to ten times his base salary. This stock ownership requirement is among the highest of any CEO in the Fortune 100. Although Mr.&nbsp;Cook was expected to satisfy
the stock ownership guideline within five years of its implementation in 2012, he already satisfies the guideline. As of December&nbsp;26, 2013, Mr.&nbsp;Cook owned shares of the Company&#146;s common stock with a value equal to approximately 35
times his base salary. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Cash Compensation.</I> Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s base salary of $1,400,000 has remained the same since
November 2011. Mr.&nbsp;Cook participates in the same performance-based bonus program as the other named executive officers and has the same target and maximum bonus levels of 100% and 200%, respectively, of his base salary. Despite the fact that
the Company has the highest revenue, operating income, and market capitalization of any of the primary peer group companies, Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s target annual cash compensation remains significantly below the median annual cash compensation level
for CEOs at peer companies. This positioning relative to peer companies is based on data supplied by F.W. Cook in its review of publicly available data as of September&nbsp;28, 2013. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Determining Compensation for the Other Named Executive Officers </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Team-Based Approach</I>. Each named executive officer is a member of the Company&#146;s executive team. The Company&#146;s executive
compensation program is intended to promote and maintain stability within the executive team. Each named executive officer has been an employee of the Company for at least 15 years. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Performance Expectations.</I> The compensation program for the executive team rests on two principles. First, each executive officer
must demonstrate exceptional personal performance in order to remain part of the executive team. The Company believes that executives who underperform should either be removed from the executive team with their compensation adjusted accordingly, or
be dismissed from the Company. Second, each executive officer must contribute as a member of the executive team to the Company&#146;s overall success rather than focus solely on specific objectives within the officer&#146;s area of responsibility.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Internal Equity</I>. Because the Company&#146;s executive officers operate as a team, the Compensation Committee considers
internal pay equity to be an important factor in the Compensation Committee&#146;s decisions on executive compensation. As a result, the compensation awarded to each of Messrs. Oppenheimer, Cue, Riccio, and Williams in 2013 was largely the same.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Discretion and Judgment of the Compensation Committee </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Compensation Committee determines all compensation for the named executive officers. Each year, the Compensation Committee conducts an evaluation of each named executive officer to determine if
changes in the officer&#146;s compensation are appropriate based on the considerations described below. At the Compensation Committee&#146;s request, Mr.&nbsp;Cook provides input for the Compensation Committee regarding the performance and
appropriate compensation of the other named executive officers. The Compensation Committee gives considerable weight to Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s evaluation of the other named executive officers because of his direct knowledge of each executive
officer&#146;s performance and contributions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>The Role of the Compensation Consultant</I>. The Compensation Committee
selected and directly retained the services of F.W. Cook, an independent executive compensation consulting firm, as to its compensation decisions for 2013. F.W. Cook did not provide any other services to the Company and worked with the
Company&#146;s management only on matters for which the Compensation Committee is responsible. The Compensation Committee assessed the independence of F.W. Cook pursuant to SEC and Nasdaq rules and concluded that no conflict of interest exists that
would prevent F.W. Cook from serving as an independent consultant to the Compensation Committee. The Compensation Committee periodically sought input from F.W. Cook on a range </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">26 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
of external market factors, including evolving compensation trends, appropriate peer companies and market survey data. F.W. Cook also provided general observations about the Company&#146;s
compensation programs, but it did not determine or recommend the amount or form of compensation for the named executive officers. Finally, F.W. Cook provided general observations in connection with the Compensation Committee&#146;s consideration of
the proposed Apple Inc. 2014 Employee Stock Plan, but it did not determine or recommend any specific share limits for the plan. The Compensation Committee intends to review the appointment of its independent executive compensation consulting firm
annually. As part of the review process, the Compensation Committee will consider the independence of the firm in accordance with applicable SEC and Nasdaq rules. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>The Role of Peer Companies and Benchmarking</I>. With the assistance of F.W. Cook, the Compensation Committee identified a group of primary peer companies to use for compensation comparison purposes
for 2013. In determining the primary peer group, the Compensation Committee selected U.S.-based, stand-alone, publicly traded companies that, in its view, compete with the Company for talent and are in one of the following industries: communications
equipment, computers and peripherals, diversified telecommunications services, internet and catalog retail, internet software and services, media, semiconductors and semiconductor equipment, or software. The threshold revenue and market
capitalization requirements for a company to be considered for the peer group remained consistent with 2012 levels at $15 billion and $25 billion, respectively. Applying these criteria, Dell Inc. was removed and CBS Corporation, eBay Inc., and Time
Warner Cable Inc. were added to the primary peer group used for compensation comparison purposes. Based on these criteria, the Company is significantly larger than the other companies in the primary peer group, with 2013 revenues of $170.9 billion
and market capitalization of $434.1 billion at the end of 2013. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Committee selected the following primary peer group for
2013: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">*</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">21</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">st</SUP></FONT><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> Century Fox was used for peer comparison purposes following News Corporation&#146;s separation into two independent, publicly traded companies. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In 2012, the Compensation Committee established a secondary peer group of general industry &#147;mega-cap&#148; companies to provide a
broader perspective on pay levels and practices for companies whose revenues and market capitalization were generally more comparable to the Company than to those in the primary peer group. The thresholds for inclusion in the secondary peer group
are $75 billion in revenue and a 12-month average market capitalization of $150 billion. Companies that are already included in the primary peer group are excluded. Using the same criteria, the following secondary peer group for 2013 remained the
same as in 2012: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P><DIV ALIGN="right">
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="94%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE">


<TR>
<TD WIDTH="51%"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" WIDTH="2%"></TD>
<TD WIDTH="47%"></TD></TR>


<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Berkshire Hathaway Inc.</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">General Electric Company</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Chevron Corporation</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Procter &amp; Gamble Co.</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Exxon Mobil Corporation</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Wal-Mart Stores Inc.</FONT></TD></TR>
</TABLE></DIV> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Unless otherwise specified, references in this Compensation Discussion and Analysis to peer
companies include both the primary and the secondary peer group companies. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Compensation Committee reviews both
compensation and performance at peer companies to inform its decision-making process so it can set total compensation levels that it believes are commensurate with the </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">27 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px;padding-bottom:0px; "><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
Company&#146;s performance. The Compensation Committee, however, does not set compensation components to meet specific benchmarks, such as targeting salaries &#147;above the median&#148; or
equity compensation &#147;at the 75</FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><SUP STYLE="vertical-align:baseline; position:relative; bottom:.8ex">th</SUP></FONT><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"> percentile.&#148;
The Compensation Committee further believes that over-reliance on benchmarking can result in compensation that is unrelated to the value delivered by the named executive officers because compensation benchmarking does not take into account the
specific performance of the named executive officers or the performance of the Company. Except as otherwise noted, the Compensation Committee&#146;s executive compensation determinations are subjective and the result of the Compensation
Committee&#146;s business judgment, which is informed by the experiences of the members of the Compensation Committee as well as the input from, and peer group data provided by, the Compensation Committee&#146;s independent executive compensation
consultant. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Consideration of Say-on-Pay Vote Results</I>. The Company provides its shareholders with the opportunity to
cast an annual advisory vote on executive compensation (a &#147;<I>say-on-pay proposal</I>&#148;). At the Company&#146;s 2013 annual meeting of shareholders, approximately 61% of the votes cast on the say-on-pay proposal were voted in favor of the
proposal. Prior to the 2013 annual meeting and continuing throughout the year, the Company&#146;s management engaged in outreach discussions with many of its largest shareholders. Ms.&nbsp;Jung, as Chair of the Compensation Committee, participated
in a number of these discussions. In general, the shareholders supported the Company&#146;s compensation practices and supported the Company&#146;s proposal to attach performance criteria to a portion of the Company&#146;s future executive equity
awards that have been entirely time-based in the past. At Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s request, the Compensation Committee began this initiative by amending his 2011 RSU award to include performance-based vesting conditions (as explained in more detail
above). Finally, to further enhance the link between named executive officers&#146; and shareholders&#146; interests, the Company implemented stock ownership guidelines for named executive officers (as explained in more detail below) to supplement
the guidelines that were implemented for Mr.&nbsp;Cook in November 2012. Mr.&nbsp;Cook already satisfies the guidelines by owning shares of the Company&#146;s stock with a value equal to approximately 35 times his base salary. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company believes these actions directly address the concerns of the Company&#146;s shareholders. The Company&#146;s management
continues to engage in dialogue with its large shareholders, and the Compensation Committee will continue to consider the results of the Company&#146;s say-on-pay votes when making future compensation decisions for the named executive officers.
</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>ELEMENTS OF THE COMPENSATION PROGRAM AND 2013 COMPENSATION </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s current executive compensation program is simple in design. It consists of three components, listed in order of their importance: </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Long-term equity awards in the form of RSUs under the Company&#146;s shareholder-approved employee incentive plan (currently, the Company&#146;s 2003
Employee Stock Plan (the &#147;<I>2003 Plan</I>&#148;)); </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Annual performance-based cash bonuses under the 2003 Plan; and </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Base salaries. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company emphasizes long-term equity awards and annual performance-based cash bonuses so that a substantial portion of each executive&#146;s total compensation opportunity is linked directly to the
Company&#146;s stock price or otherwise driven by performance. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The named executive officers are also eligible to participate
in the Company&#146;s health and welfare programs, Employee Stock Purchase Plan, 401(k) plan, matching gifts program, and other broad-based programs on the same basis as other employees. </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">28 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>The Role of Long-Term Equity Awards </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Emphasis on RSUs</I>. The Company has traditionally believed that long-term equity awards in the form of RSUs are the most effective
way to attract and retain a talented executive team and align executives&#146; interests with those of shareholders. Accordingly, the Company&#146;s executive compensation program in recent years has been weighted considerably toward long-term
equity awards rather than cash compensation. The Company believes RSUs create incentives for performance and further align executives&#146; interests with those of shareholders because an RSU&#146;s value increases or decreases in conjunction with
the Company&#146;s stock price. As explained in more detail above, the Company is committed to including performance criteria in a portion of the equity awards it grants to executive officers in the future. At Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s request, the
Compensation Committee began this initiative in 2013 by amending his 2011 RSU award to include performance-based vesting conditions. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Frequency of Equity Awards and Impact on the Summary Compensation Table</I>. In general, the Company&#146;s recent practice has been to grant equity awards to executives, other than the CEO,
approximately every two fiscal years (with limited exceptions for special cases, such as awards to new hires or in connection with promotions). Consistent with this practice, the Company did not grant any equity awards to its executive officers in
2013. In accordance with applicable SEC rules, the table entitled &#147;Summary Compensation Table&#151;2013, 2012, and 2011&#148; includes as compensation for each named executive officer the full grant-date fair value (as determined under
generally accepted accounting principles) for all equity awards granted to the named executive officer during each year shown in the table. Accordingly, the compensation shown for each named executive officer will generally be comparatively high for
the years in which the Company grants RSU awards to the officers and comparatively low for the years in which the Company does not grant RSU awards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Long Vesting Periods Maximize Retention and Support Long-Term Focus</I>. The Company believes granting awards with long vesting periods creates a substantial retention incentive and also encourages the
named executive officers to focus on the Company&#146;s long-term business objectives and long-term stock price performance. The Compensation Committee has discretion to grant awards with different vesting schedules for new hires or employees who
are promoted to the executive team, and in special cases as determined by the Compensation Committee. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Dividend
Equivalents</I>. Dividend equivalents accrue on all unvested RSUs, other than RSUs held by Mr.&nbsp;Cook, and are paid out on the vesting of the underlying RSUs. The crediting of dividend equivalents is meant to preserve the equity-based incentives
intended by the Company when the awards were granted and to treat employees with RSU awards consistently with shareholders. As noted above, at Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s request, his RSU awards do not participate in dividend equivalents. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>The Role of Cash Compensation </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Overview</I>. The named executive officers&#146; cash compensation consists of base salaries and performance-based cash bonuses. In October 2012, the Compensation Committee increased the base salaries
of the named executive officers, other than Mr.&nbsp;Cook, as noted below. There were no changes to the performance-based cash bonus program for the executive officers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Despite the salary increases and the fact that the Company has the highest revenue, operating income, and market capitalization of any of the primary peer group companies, the target annual cash
compensation for the named executive officers is significantly below the median for executives with similar positions at peer companies. This positioning relative to peer companies is based on data supplied by F.W. Cook in its review of publicly
available data as of September&nbsp;28, 2013. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Base Salaries</I>. Base salaries are customary and help attract and retain
executives. In October 2012, the Company announced changes to the executive team to encourage even more collaboration between the Company&#146;s hardware, software, and services teams. Following this announcement, the Compensation Committee
</FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">29 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
increased the base salary of the executive officers, other than Mr.&nbsp;Cook, from $800,000 to $875,000. This change was intended to recognize the additional responsibilities assigned to the
officers, as well as their exceptional individual performance, and to maintain internal equity among the executive team. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Performance-Based Cash Bonuses</I>. The Compensation Committee awards performance-based cash bonuses to compensate the named executive
officers for achieving the Company&#146;s annual performance goals. The target and maximum bonus levels for the named executive officers remained the same in 2013 at 100% and 200%, respectively, of each officer&#146;s base salary. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The bonuses represent a relatively small percentage of the executives&#146; total compensation given the Company&#146;s emphasis on
long-term equity awards. In addition, the Company prefers to emphasize long-term shareholder value creation over annual operating results. Accordingly, the bonus program is modestly funded relative to those generally in place at peer companies, as
reflected by the following: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The target bonus of 100% of base salary is lower than those of peer companies, where median target bonus levels of executives with similar positions
range from 143% to 189% of base salary; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The maximum bonus of 200% of base salary for exceptional performance is lower than the maximum bonus levels generally provided at peer companies; and
</FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company has no long-term cash bonus program. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Performance Criteria</I>. The performance criteria used to determine the annual bonuses for the named executive officers were net sales and operating income as determined in accordance with generally
accepted accounting principles. These criteria were chosen because they reflect commonly recognized measures of overall company performance and are associated with the creation of value for shareholders. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Performance Goals</I>. Performance goals are set at target and maximum levels based on objectives in the Company&#146;s internal
business plan. The target and maximum net sales performance goals for 2013 were set at approximately 22% and 21% higher, respectively, than the target and maximum net sales performance goals approved under the Company&#146;s 2012 bonus program, and
at levels that were greater than the Company&#146;s actual net sales for 2012. The target and maximum operating income performance goals for 2013 were each set approximately 16% higher than the target and maximum operating income performance goals
approved under the Company&#146;s 2012 bonus program, and at levels that were significantly greater than the Company&#146;s actual 2011 operating income but less than the Company&#146;s actual 2012 operating income. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Compensation Committee believed that the Company&#146;s operating income for 2012 would be difficult to repeat in 2013, in part,
because the Company&#146;s business plan for 2013 included the introduction of new versions of existing products with higher cost structures and flat or reduced pricing, the introduction of iPad mini with gross margin significantly below the
Company&#146;s average product margins, and price reductions on certain products, including iPad 2 and iPhone 4. The Committee believed that significant leadership efforts would be required to achieve the 2013 performance goals. The table below
shows the target and maximum goals and the Company&#146;s actual performance for 2013. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="center">

<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">

<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Payout Structure</I>. The payout structure is based on an equal weighting of operating income and net
sales because each measure is considered equally important in the Company&#146;s internal business plan. The performance-based cash bonuses are defined as a percentage of the executive&#146;s base salary, and payouts are
</FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">30 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
interpolated for achievement of performance between the target and maximum goals. No payout is made relative to a particular performance criterion unless the target performance goal is achieved
with respect to that criterion. The payout structure in effect for 2013 is shown in the table below. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" NOWRAP> <P STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000;width:73pt"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>Performance Criteria</B></FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center" STYLE="border-bottom:1px solid #000000"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="1"><B>2013&nbsp;Payout&nbsp;Based&nbsp;on&nbsp;Actual&nbsp;Performance</B></FONT></TD></TR>


<TR BGCOLOR="#cceeff">
<TD VALIGN="top"> <P STYLE="margin-left:1.00em; text-indent:-1.00em"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Net Sales</FONT></P></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">50%</FONT></TD>

<TR>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;&nbsp;</TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD VALIGN="bottom"></TD>

<TD VALIGN="bottom"> <P STYLE="border-top:3px double #000000">&nbsp;</P></TD></TR>
</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">At the end of the year, the Compensation Committee determines the amount of the bonus to be paid to each
executive officer by comparing the Company&#146;s financial results to the performance goals. The Committee also considered the Company&#146;s 2013 results relative to peer companies, and it recognized that the Company&#146;s net sales and operating
income were significantly higher than any of the primary peer group companies. The Compensation Committee may, in its discretion, reduce (but not increase) the amount of any individual bonus based on its subjective assessment of the officer&#146;s
overall performance. In 2013, the Company exceeded the maximum performance goals for both net sales and operating income, and the Compensation Committee determined that no downward adjustments to the bonuses would be made based on individual
performance. As a result, the Compensation Committee awarded the named executive officers performance-based cash bonuses equal to 200% of their base salaries. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>No Employment Agreements or Other Arrangements </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The named executive
officers are employed at will. Based on the Company&#146;s philosophy that its executive compensation program should be simple and directly linked to performance, the compensation program for the named executive officers does <U>not</U> include any
of the following pay practices: </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Employment agreements; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Severance arrangements; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Cash payments in connection with a change in control of the Company; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TR>

<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Tax gross-ups; </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Supplemental executive retirement benefits; or </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">&#149;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="1%" VALIGN="top"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"> <P ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Supplemental health or insurance benefits. </FONT></P></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In addition, as explained above, the Company does not provide tax reimbursements to the named executive officers, nor does it provide perquisites or change in control benefits to its officers that are not
available to employees generally. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Governance and Other Considerations </I></B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Tax Deductibility of Compensation Expense</I>. Section&nbsp;162(m) of the Internal Revenue Code (the &#147;<I>Code</I>&#148;) places a
$1 million limit on the amount of compensation the Company can deduct in any one year for compensation paid to the chief executive officer and the three most highly-compensated executive officers employed by the Company at the end of the year (other
than the Company&#146;s chief financial officer). However, the $1 million deduction limit generally does not apply to compensation that is performance-based and provided under a shareholder-approved plan. While the Compensation Committee considers
the deductibility of awards as </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">31 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
one factor in determining executive compensation, the Compensation Committee also looks at other factors in making its decisions as noted above and retains the flexibility to grant awards it
determines to be consistent with the Company&#146;s goal for its executive compensation program even if the award is not deductible by the Company for tax purposes. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company&#146;s performance-based cash bonuses are intended to be excluded from the $1 million deduction limit because they are paid based on achievement of pre-determined performance goals established
by the Compensation Committee pursuant to the 2003 Plan.&nbsp;In addition, as a result of the modification of Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s 2011 RSU award to add pre-determined performance criteria,&nbsp;the tranches of the award subject to performance
criteria with measurement periods that begin after the modification are expected to be excluded from the $1 million&nbsp;deduction limit. However, the Company&#146;s&nbsp;RSU awards&nbsp;with only time-based vesting requirements, and the tranche of
Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s 2011 RSU award with a&nbsp;performance measurement period that commenced before the date of the modification,&nbsp;do not qualify for tax deductibility under Section&nbsp;162(m) to the extent the $1 million limit
is&nbsp;exceeded. As discussed above, the Company is committed to including performance criteria&nbsp;in a portion of future equity awards granted to executive officers. The Company will consider tax deductibility under Section&nbsp;162(m) as it
designs future equity awards with&nbsp;performance-based vesting conditions to executive officers. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Clawback of RSU
Awards.</I> The named executive officers&#146; RSU awards are granted under the Company&#146;s standard RSU agreement. This agreement requires an employee to deliver or otherwise repay to the Company any shares or other amount that may be paid in
respect of an RSU award in the event the employee commits a felony, engages in a breach of confidentiality, commits an act of theft, embezzlement or fraud, or materially breaches any agreement with the Company. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Prohibition on Hedging and Short Sales</I>. The Company prohibits short sales and transactions in derivatives of Company securities,
including hedging transactions, for all directors and officers of the Company. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Stock Ownership Guidelines.</I> Under the
Company&#146;s stock ownership guidelines, Mr.&nbsp;Cook is expected to own shares of Company common stock that have a value equal to ten times his base salary. As discussed above, Mr.&nbsp;Cook already satisfies the guideline. Other named executive
officers are expected to own shares that have a value equal to three times their base salary. This guideline is expected to be satisfied by the later of February&nbsp;6, 2018 or within five years after an officer first becomes subject to the
guideline. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Risk Considerations</I>. The Compensation Committee considers, in establishing and reviewing the executive
compensation program, whether the program encourages unnecessary or excessive risk taking and has concluded that it does not. See the section entitled &#147;Board Oversight of Risk Management&#148; above for an additional discussion of risk
considerations. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>Compensation Decisions for 2014 </I></B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>Performance Conditions on Future Equity Awards</I>. The Company has not yet determined the terms and conditions of any equity awards to be granted to the named executive officers in 2014; however, as
noted above, the Company is committed to including performance criteria in a portion of the equity awards it grants to executive officers in the future. </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">32 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>(i) Aggregate Grant Date Fair Value of RSUs Awarded in 2012. </I></B>In accordance with SEC rules,
the amounts shown in Column&nbsp;(e) for 2012 include the aggregate grant date fair value of stock awards during 2012. These values have been determined under the principles used to calculate the grant date fair value of equity awards for purposes
of the Company&#146;s financial statements. As noted in &#147;Executive Compensation&#151;Compensation Discussion and Analysis&#148; above, the Company&#146;s recent practice has been to grant regular RSU awards to the named executive officers
(other than the CEO) every two fiscal years, with limited exceptions for special cases, such as awards to new hires or in connection with promotions. As a result, the </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">33 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">
compensation reported for each named executive officer will generally be comparatively high for the years in which the Company grants RSU awards to the officers and comparatively low for the
years in which the Company does not grant RSU awards. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; margin-left:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B><I>(ii) Accounting Charges due to RSU Modification to Provide
Dividend Equivalents. </I></B>The amounts shown in Column&nbsp;(e) for Peter Oppenheimer, Eduardo Cue and Jeffrey Williams in 2012 include the incremental fair value, computed in accordance with FASB Topic 718, of the modification of those
officers&#146; RSUs on May&nbsp;24, 2012 to provide for dividend equivalents. No additional RSUs were awarded as part of that modification. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

performance of the Company and the individual executive relative to pre-determined objectives for the year. The target and maximum amounts for each named executive officer&#146;s 2013 bonus opportunity are shown in the table entitled &#147;Grants of
Plan-Based Awards&#151;2013.&#148; The Company exceeded the maximum performance goals for both net sales and operating income set by the Compensation Committee for 2013. Accordingly, each executive officer received the maximum payout of 200% of base
salary under the performance-based bonus plan. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

</B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The table entitled &#147;Summary Compensation Table&#151;2013, 2012, and 2011&#148; above quantifies the value of the
different forms of compensation of each named executive officer for services rendered during 2013, 2012, and 2011. The primary elements of each named executive officer&#146;s total compensation shown in the table are base salary, an annual bonus,
and long-term equity awards consisting of RSUs. Named executive officers also received the other benefits listed in Column (g)&nbsp;of the table entitled &#147;Summary Compensation Table&#151;2013, 2012, and 2011,&#148; as further described in the
footnotes to the table. The Company does not have employment agreements or severance arrangements with any named executive officer. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The table entitled &#147;Summary Compensation Table&#151;2013, 2012, and 2011&#148; should be read in conjunction with the following tables and narrative descriptions. The table entitled &#147;Grants of
Plan-Based Awards&#151;2013&#148; and the accompanying description provide information regarding the bonus opportunities awarded to named executive officers in 2013. The tables entitled &#147;Outstanding Equity Awards at 2013 Year-End&#148; and
&#147;Option Exercises and Stock Vested&#151;2013&#148; provide further information on the named executive officers&#146; potential realizable value and actual value realized with respect to their equity awards. </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">34 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

</TABLE> <P STYLE="margin-top:18px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Description of Plan-Based Awards </B></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:6px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Each of the &#147;Non-Equity Incentive Plan Awards&#148; shown in the table entitled &#147;Grants of Plan-Based Awards&#151;2013&#148; was granted under the 2003 Plan, which provides flexibility to grant
non-equity incentive awards (i.e., cash bonus opportunities), as well as equity awards. The material terms of the 2013 non-equity incentive awards are described under &#147;Executive Compensation&#151;Compensation Discussion and Analysis&#148; in
the section entitled &#147;The Role of Cash Compensation.&#148; </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">No new RSU awards were granted to the named executive
officers in 2013. The material terms of the Company&#146;s equity incentive awards are described under &#147;Executive Compensation&#151;Compensation Discussion and Analysis&#148; in the section entitled &#147;The Role of Long Term Equity
Awards.&#148; A detailed description of the modification of Mr.&nbsp;Cook&#146;s 2011 RSU award is set forth in the Compensation Discussion and Analysis beginning on page 23 in the section entitled &#147;Determining Compensation for the Chief
Executive Officer.&#148; </FONT></P>
 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">35 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(1)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The dollar amounts shown in Columns&nbsp;(d) and (f)&nbsp;are determined by multiplying (x)&nbsp;the number of shares or units shown in Column (c)&nbsp;or (e), as
applicable,&nbsp;by (y)&nbsp;$482.75 (the closing price of the Company&#146;s common stock on September&nbsp;27, 2013, the last trading day of the Company&#146;s fiscal year). </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>

<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(2)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This RSU award is scheduled to vest in its entirety on September&nbsp;21, 2014, provided that the officer continues to be employed with the Company through the vesting
date. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE> <P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" BORDER="0" CELLPADDING="0" CELLSPACING="0" WIDTH="100%">
<TR>
<TD WIDTH="4%" VALIGN="top" ALIGN="left"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(3)</FONT></TD>
<TD ALIGN="left" VALIGN="top"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">This RSU award was modified on June&nbsp;21, 2013 to add performance criteria, as discussed under &#147;Executive Compensation&#151;Compensation Discussion and
Analysis&#148; in the section entitled &#147;Determining Compensation for the Chief Executive Officer.&#148; Pursuant to the modification, 100,000 RSUs subject to the award are scheduled to vest on each of August&nbsp;24, 2016 and August&nbsp;24,
2021, provided that the officer continues to be employed with the Company through the applicable vesting date. The remaining 640,000 RSUs subject to the award are separated into eight equal tranches of 80,000 RSUs that are each scheduled to vest
annually commencing August&nbsp;24, 2014, assuming continued employment through the applicable vesting date and, with respect to a portion of each tranche, satisfaction of applicable performance-based criteria. </FONT></TD></TR></TABLE>
<P STYLE="font-size:6px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>

<TD VALIGN="bottom" ALIGN="right"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">30,333,895</FONT></TD>
<TD NOWRAP VALIGN="bottom"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">(4)&nbsp;</FONT></TD></TR>
<TR>

 <p STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px"><FONT SIZE="1">&nbsp;</FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">38 </FONT></P>



<p Style='page-break-before:always'>
<HR  SIZE="3" style="COLOR:#999999" WIDTH="100%" ALIGN="CENTER">

 <P STYLE="margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>AUDIT COMMITTEE REPORT </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><I>The following is the report of the Audit Committee with respect to the Company&#146;s audited financial statements for the year ended
September&nbsp;28, 2013. The information contained in this report shall not be deemed &#147;soliciting material&#148; or otherwise considered &#147;filed&#148; with the SEC, and such information shall not be incorporated by reference into any future
filing under the Securities Act or the Exchange Act except to the extent that the Company specifically incorporates such information by reference in such filing. </I></FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Audit Committee consists of four members: Drs. Levinson and Sugar and Messrs. Campbell and Iger. All the members are independent directors under the Nasdaq and SEC audit committee structure and
membership requirements. The Audit Committee has certain duties and powers as described in its written charter adopted by the Board. A copy of the charter can be found on the Company&#146;s website at www.apple.com/investor. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Audit Committee is responsible primarily for assisting the Board in fulfilling its oversight responsibility of reviewing the
financial information that will be provided to shareholders and others, appointing the independent registered public accounting firm, reviewing the services performed by the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm and internal
audit department, evaluating the Company&#146;s accounting policies and the Company&#146;s system of internal controls that management and the Board have established, reviewing significant financial transactions, and overseeing enterprise risk
management. The Audit Committee does not itself prepare financial statements or perform audits, and its members are not auditors or certifiers of the Company&#146;s financial statements. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">In fulfilling its oversight responsibility of appointing and reviewing the services performed by the Company&#146;s independent
registered public accounting firm, the Audit Committee carefully reviews the policies and procedures for the engagement of the independent registered public accounting firm, including the scope of the audit, audit fees, auditor independence matters
and the extent to which the independent registered public accounting firm may be retained to perform non-audit related services. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT
STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Company maintains an auditor independence policy that bans its auditors from performing non-financial consulting services, such as information technology consulting and internal audit services. This
policy mandates that the Audit Committee approve the audit and non-audit services and related budget in advance, and that the Audit Committee be provided with quarterly reporting on actual spending. This policy also mandates that the Company may not
enter into auditor engagements for non-audit services without the Audit Committee&#146;s express approval. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Audit
Committee has reviewed and discussed the audited financial statements for the year ended September&nbsp;28, 2013 with the Company&#146;s management and Ernst&nbsp;&amp; Young LLP, the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm
(&#147;<I>EY</I>&#148;). The Audit Committee has also discussed with EY the matters required to be discussed by Auditing Standard No.&nbsp;16, &#147;Communications with Audit Committees&#148; issued by the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board
(&#147;<I>PCAOB</I>&#148;). </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">The Audit Committee also has received and reviewed the written disclosures and the letter from EY
required by applicable requirements of the PCAOB regarding EY&#146;s communications with the Audit Committee concerning independence, and has discussed with EY its independence from the Company. </FONT></P>
<P STYLE="margin-top:12px;margin-bottom:0px; text-indent:4%"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Based on the reviews and discussions referred to above, the Audit Committee recommended to the Board that the financial statements
referred to above be included in the Annual Report. </FONT></P> <P STYLE="margin-top:24px;margin-bottom:0px" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2"><B>Members of the Audit Committee </B></FONT></P>
<P STYLE="font-size:12px;margin-top:0px;margin-bottom:0px">&nbsp;</P>
<TABLE CELLSPACING="0" CELLPADDING="0" WIDTH="100%" BORDER="0" STYLE="BORDER-COLLAPSE:COLLAPSE" ALIGN="center">

<TD VALIGN="top" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">Ronald&nbsp;Sugar&nbsp;(Chair)</FONT></TD>

<TD VALIGN="top" ALIGN="center"><FONT STYLE="font-family:Times New Roman" SIZE="2">William&nbsp;Campbell</FONT></TD>
